causes: A virus (ToMV) primarily spread through **mechanical contact** (touching infected plants, contaminated hands, tools, or clothing). Can also be spread by seeds.
remedy: There is no chemical cure** for viral diseases. Immediately **remove and destroy** (burn or bag and discard) infected plants. Disinfect all tools and surfaces with a 10% bleach solution.
prevention: Use **certified virus-free seeds/transplants**. Choose **resistant varieties**. Practice strict hygiene: wash hands thoroughly after handling tobacco products or suspected plants. Disinfect tools frequently.

causes: Oomycete pathogen (*Phytophthora infestans*). Favored by **cool, wet weather** (temperatures between 60°F and 78°F) and **high humidity**.
remedy: Apply approved **fungicides** (e.g., chlorothalonil, mancozeb) immediately upon first symptoms. **Remove and destroy** heavily infected foliage and fruit.
prevention: Use **resistant varieties**. Ensure **proper plant spacing** for good air circulation. Apply **preventative fungicides** when weather conditions favor the disease. Avoid overhead watering.

causes: Fungus (*Corynespora cassiicola*). Thrives in **warm temperatures** (77°F to 86°F) and periods of **leaf wetness** (high humidity).
remedy: Apply **fungicides** labeled for target spot (e.g., those containing strobilurins). **Remove infected plant debris** from the soil surface to reduce inoculum.
prevention: Practice **crop rotation** (at least 2-3 years without tomato/pepper/potato). Use **disease-free seeds**. Improve air circulation and avoid prolonged leaf wetness.

causes: Fungus (*Passalora fulva*). Primarily a problem in protected cultivation (greenhouses) where **humidity is very high** (over 85%) and temperatures are moderate (68°F–77°F).
remedy: Improve **air circulation and ventilation** to drop humidity below 85%. Apply appropriate **fungicides** (e.g., copper-based or chlorothalonil).
prevention: Use **resistant tomato varieties**. Ensure **excellent ventilation** in greenhouses. Avoid overhead irrigation and reduce planting density.

causes: Oomycete pathogen (*Phytophthora infestans*). Same as tomato late blight, flourishing in **cool, wet weather**.
remedy: Apply approved **fungicides** (often a combination of systemic and protectant types). **Destroy all infected tubers, haulms, and volunteer potato plants**.
prevention: Use **certified disease-free seed potatoes**. Practice **hilling** (mounding soil around the stems) to prevent spores from washing down to the tubers. Apply preventative fungicides.

causes: Four species of **bacteria** (*Xanthomonas spp.*). Spread by splashing rain, overhead irrigation, and infected tools. Favored by **warm and rainy/humid conditions**.
remedy: Apply **copper-based bactericides** often mixed with mancozeb. This primarily helps **slow the spread**, as bactericides do not cure existing spots.
prevention: Use **certified disease-free seeds/transplants**. Choose highly **resistant varieties**. Avoid **working in the field when foliage is wet**. Practice **crop rotation**.

causes: Infestation by a tiny pest (**mite**) (*Tetranychus urticae*). Thrives in **hot, dry conditions** and dusty environments.
remedy: Apply targeted **miticides** (not standard insecticides). Use **biological controls** (e.g., predatory mites). For small infestations, a strong jet of water can dislodge them.
prevention: Maintain **adequate soil moisture** and humidity (mites dislike high humidity). Check the undersides of leaves regularly for webbing or tiny spots (stippling).

causes: A **virus** (*TYLCV*) transmitted **exclusively** by the **Whitefly** (*Bemisia tabaci*). The whitefly carries the virus from infected to healthy plants.
remedy: There is **no cure** for the virus. **Remove and destroy** infected plants immediately to prevent the whitefly from spreading it to others. Control the vector (whitefly).
prevention: Use **resistant or tolerant varieties**. Aggressively **control whiteflies** with insecticides or reflective plastic mulch. Use fine-mesh nets or row covers to exclude the pest.

causes: Bacteria (*Xanthomonas spp.*), same as the tomato disease. Spread through water, favored by **warm, humid weather**.
remedy: Apply **copper-based bactericides** and mancozeb to manage the spread, especially important during periods of high moisture.
prevention: Use **certified disease-free seeds** and water-tested transplants. Select **resistant pepper varieties**. Avoid overhead irrigation and practice **crop rotation**.

causes: Fungus (*Alternaria solani*). Favored by **warm, moist conditions** and often affects older, stressed plants (e.g., after tuber set).
remedy: Apply protective **fungicides** (e.g., chlorothalonil, mancozeb) to prevent new infections. Ensure good fertility and watering to reduce plant stress.
prevention: Practice a **3-year crop rotation**. Maintain a balanced fertilization program to prevent stress. Apply preventative fungicides during the growing season, particularly before flowering.

causes: Fungus (*Septoria lycopersici*). Favored by **warm, humid weather** (temperatures 68°F–77°F) and periods of **high leaf wetness**.
remedy: Apply approved **fungicides** (e.g., chlorothalonil, mancozeb). **Prune infected leaves** (only when dry) to reduce spore sources.
prevention: **Crop rotation** (1-2 years). Stake or cage plants to keep foliage off the ground and improve air flow. Water the base of the plant, avoiding leaves.

causes: Fungus (*Alternaria solani*). Same as potato early blight, common in tomato under **warm, moist conditions**.
remedy: Apply approved **fungicides** (e.g., chlorothalonil, mancozeb) regularly. **Prune out the lowest, oldest infected leaves** to slow spread.
prevention: Practice **crop rotation**. Plant in well-drained soil. Keep the soil surface covered with **mulch** to prevent fungal spores from splashing onto the lower leaves.

Use **certified disease-free seeds**. Maintain **consistent watering** and fertilization to avoid stress. Stake or cage plants for **maximum air circulation**. Practice a **3-4 year crop rotation** with non-host crops.

Use **certified seed potatoes** that are firm and disease-free. Plant in **well-drained soil**. Practice **hilling** to cover emerging stems and protect tubers. Follow a strict **4-year crop rotation**.
Use **certified disease-free seeds/transplants**. Plant in a **warm location with well-drained soil**. Water regularly and consistently at the base of the plant. Practice **crop rotation**.
